Ramy Kandil
All the sex, money & drugs; people who live like that never end up happy. Yes, but neither do you. In the meantime they've had all the sex, money & drugs.
Sep 28, 2015

And If You Go…

How do you describe utter and complete loss? How do you explain the feeling of having something or someone who were part of the fabric of your being no longer being there? How do you condition your mind to accept being cast aside? How do you come to fathom what it is to live under the spell of abandonment?

Abandonment isn’t just a singularity. For some of us, abandonment takes successive turns in one’s life. You lose people. You lose feelings. You lose desires. This cumulative abandonment has a profound effect on your emotional well being. You start to think that this must be happening because you are of no value. You have nothing to offer, nothing anyone wants at least — so they leave. If you mattered, how could they?

It’s not very easy to relate if you’ve never experienced it yourself. Being abandoned is a lot like being born. Your familiar, safe and cushiony (albeit wet) surroundings are no longer there. You are expelled to the unfamiliar, unknown and dry reality of the world. Everything you once knew and held dear, things that defined who you are — gone. Abandonment is about losing the connection. You’re cut off. It’s the manifestation of the loss of love. Abandonment is a reflection of fear. The fear of being alone.

Abandonment isn’t always an active process. It doesn’t always happen like it does in a film, you don’t have a big life-changing talk with one of you walking out on the other, never to be heard from again. That’s what you get if you’re lucky.

There’s the abandonment that takes its time. The one where you can both see it happening — but can’t do anything to stop it. You can see the end even though it hasn’t yet begun. It starts innocently enough — just a feeling like something isn’t quite “right”. Words lessen. Eyes falter. Days get longer. Things get left unsaid. Feelings shoved aside. One day one of you speaks out. You both shrug it off as something that was both inevitable and known. You drift apart. This isn’t so much an abandonment of one person to another as it is a mutual abandonment of a once-shared belief in something common. You’ve abandoned the ideal. You’ve both abandoned each other.

The real gut wrenching abandonment is the one where they simply just disappear. You’re left with but a 1,000,001 questions. You’ll never get answers. You’ll always wonder why. How. When. Who. Where. You’ll never get answers. You will tumble and turn in bed. You will lose days, weeks and months of sleep. You will see their name and image in everything you read and gaze upon. Every stranger in a crowd will seem to resemble them. You’ll build shrines for memories. You’ll begin to detest them. Loathe them for leaving you behind without a word. You’ll hate them for how they’ve made you feel. You feel worthless. Not worthy of a face-to-face conversation, a phone call, a text message, a mere note. Nothing.

“…I will exile my thoughts if they think of you again, and I will rip my lips out if they say your name once more. Now if you do exist, I will tell you my final word in life or in death, I tell you goodbye.”
― Knut Hamsun, Hunger

You’re lucky if what you end up getting is someone walking out on you because they are weak. We always tend to think of being abandoned as something that one does as a reaction to being dealt an inexcusable offense. It isn’t usually the case. More often than not, those who abandon simply don’t have it in them to be there. Not just for you, but for themselves. It’s quite easy to judge, point fingers, draw conclusions and generalize even. Truth is, your abandoner can be someone else’s permanent. Human relationships are too complex to categorize as black and white. Sometimes abandoned people go on to become abandoners in their own right. It isn’t something you plan, exactly. Life has a funny way of throwing a curve ball your way.

Then again, there are the serial abandoners. What a grotesque breed they are. Those are individuals who derive their gratification by inflicting emotional pain onto others vis-à-vis abandonment as a demonstration of their power. They go about their entire lives exercising just that. They crave and yearn for the pleading, the begging and the crying as you get down on your knees and tell them that you’d rather die than have them leave. But they do. They always do.

They may downplay their triumph when confronted about it. They may not admit that they enjoyed the process. That they ached for the torment which they caused — they may even feel some sense of regret. But it does not prevail. They quickly assimilate into their newly found freedom and an even more inflated ego than ever before.

Let us agree that not all those who abandon set out to do so. They do not aim to go out of their way to cause harm to you or to anyone. Many abandoners are hurt by their act of abandonment themselves. Many are just like you and me, people struggling to find the right paths and the answers to life’s many unanswered questions — along with the rest of the herd.

There’s grief, and there’s abandonment grief. This is a special kind of torment. A kind that eats at you slowly and chronically. What it can do to you is nothing short of extraordinary either. How it eats at the very fabric of your being. How insecurity becomes a constant. It radically changes you from within until all you have to offer is escape. You trust nothing and entrust no one. You feel that your worth is best preserved by keeping your distance. You never want to get too close. You never want to get invested. You’ve been hurt enough.

And if you go…it’s okay. I’m strong enough for the both of us.
